notes: A clitic that is to be applied only when the owner of the noun would use a casual first person pronoun (ká, aya, cán, or zahal).
A clitic that is to be applied only when the owner of the noun would use a casual first person pronoun (ká, nyu, aya, or zahal).

etymology: From Old Rokadong *sonnan "causer, creator".
notes: Applies to nouns or verbs to indicate a person characterized by the root. When part of the compound word is a type of person, that word replaces this affix.

etymology: From Matelian "janka" (person).
notes: Applies to nouns or verbs to indicate a person characterized by the root. When part of the compound word is a type of person, that word replaces this affix.
A shortening of "lekar" (to fill).

etymology: From Old High Kanafan *heimda "like a, as a".
From Sainen "midâ" (ability).
notes: Attach to the end of words one might attach the English affix "-able" to, or for "the ability to do xyz".

etymology: Literally "Nenta letters". Rokadong's abugida is based on Classical Nenta.
Portmanteau of "ruvi nila" (inky water, literally dark blue).

notes: The <o> and especially the <h> are frequently elided when this circumfix is applied.

etymology: Clipping of igato; subsumed its meaning except in formal contexts.
Reduplication of "ravien".

notes: Technically refers specifically to Rokaselan spirits, but is frequently used as a general word for alcoholic beverages.

etymology: Literally "Calgara letters". Calgaran uses an alphabet.

notes: Used in negative clauses.

etymology: From Classical Nenta ta ye "and last".
notes: Prescribed to be used only at the end of a list, but many speakers use it for the entire list.
Derived from antaisharon "to be annoyed".
Derived from tenataishar "to cause annoyance".

etymology: From Classical Nenta nedsaka~nejaka "direction". Doublet of neshah.
From Classical Nenta nedsaka~nejaka "direction". Doublet of neshah.
From Kairitelan sefãké "to dispute, to argue against."
notes: Used instead of sefadr except in "argue with".

etymology: From Kairitelan sefãda, from Old Linnerian sevenda.
From Kairitelan sefãda "to discuss", from Old Linnerian sevenda "discourse, politics."

notes: Expresses confidence in the preceding statement, and may also be equivalent to the English tag question "you know?". Phonemically /ɾu/.

etymology: Literally "peko" + "-kil". As a result, likely meant "spherical", but was used as a noun so much it became the primary definition.
From Imperial Karanesa "fê sha" with the same meaning. Doublet of "vel".
notes: Equivalent to English "there be".
Reflexive unless causative. Used for personal, emotional, and physical changes.
Reflexive unless causative. Used for social or professional change.

etymology: Clipping of cadányangga.
notes: Originally referred to fruits from bushes specifically; semantically expanded to refer to all fruits not referred to as "kúzi".

etymology: Compound of "cadán" and "angga".
notes: Originally referred to fruits from bushes specifically; semantically expanded to refer to all fruits not referred to as "kúzi".

etymology: From "nyuwa hítar" (to get/have been born).

notes: Means specifically "to give birth"
Also refers specifically to a signboard or notice board, of the kind one puts messages on.

As in, that of a living thing - razil or koro nouns. Typically this noun is a koro noun even when it refers to something that is a razil noun, in much the same vein that parts of the body are koro nouns even when they belong to a razil noun.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa ginganak; use of /dʒ/ appears to be by analogy to native jinkir, which has the same root.

notes: While this serves both as a "stop working" and "make unusable" verb, the latter would be causative at least in "proper" Rokadong.
Used both for something on fire (nata árirpan téril = I burned the wood) and for someone injured by fire (nata árirpan laté (toká) = I burned my hand).
Basically, if the "yarit"'s trunk isn't visible without getting very close, it's a "angga."

etymology: Literally "colorful moth".

notes: Refers to rice patties or cakes, mainly, as the principal grain of Quillan is most similar to rice.

etymology: From Sanényan "tyakira" (calculate), Proto-Saneta "dakira" (count, calculate).
notes: Doublet of "count." See also akidir.

etymology: Originally a reduplication of "raisen" meaning "heavy artillery". This got simplified to its current form and suppleted the original definition of "raisen" as "cannon".
From Imperial Karanesa gûtha, with the same meaning.
notes: Refers to cattle in general; use gender adjectives for "cow" or "bull".
Holds the meaning "to forbid" as well, leading to "mayafukar" falling into disuse.
The "satai" doesn't have to be physical.

etymology: From Debazi micela "lie, false".
Portmanteau of Old Rokadong kókó and yaritə.
notes: Primarily refers to the tree; can also refer to the fruit through semantic extension, but technically the phrase "kokoya kúzi" is prescribed.

etymology: Backformation formed by likeness to Matelian "neiji" (Rokadong "naiji").

sample: Kita Barbie vel, káya gun shika to Barbie.

etymology: From Classical Nenta sonairhinia "person-beast."
From Sanényan pòlya.
notes: Commonly used in city names or city-related words, but less common for referring to "the city" in general.

etymology: Literally "pola" (from Sanenyan for city) + "ubisha" (from Sanenyan for state).
Literally "good-eyed."
From Classical Nenta fôkəya "cloth, fabric". Classical Nenta fokiyanaka was originally "clothing"; this word may have developed to resemble that one.
From Classical Nenta petao "palm tree".
From Old Rokadong firothə "silver".
notes: Especially when made of silver or nickel.

etymology: Compound of tayu "wind" + yuma "illness".
From Proto-Nenta "kidira" (count), Proto-Nensane "ngkaidi" (count).
From Classical Nenta tenmá "salt".

notes: Also describes teal. See Colors article for details.
More casual form of ''jekra''.

etymology: Portmanteau of "ruvi nila" (inky water, literally dark blue).

notes: Portmanteau of pola lítari "city night". Slang made shortly after the streetlight, which became popular in Pahang Rokadong. Does not refer to dark magic.
Refers to an unlighted place that cannot see the sky, or to dark magic.
See also "naiji".

etymology: Reduplication of "raza" (sun).
Reduplication of "raza" (sun).

notes: Misspelled / mispronounced partial reduplication of toika (which normally would be totoika). A minced oath of roken.

etymology: Portmanteau of "ruvi nila" (inky water, literally dark blue).
From Matelian asateli "diamond", ultimately from Sãdenyán hashrĩl "diamond, gemstone, wealth".

notes: Also used to refer to a direction, e.g. "straight ahead" (see also "direct").

etymology: From Kairitelan sefã "to discuss", from Old Linnerian seven "discourse, politics."

notes: From anburselir "to be disgusted".
From tenaburselir "to cause disgust".
Figuratively, this word can also refer to killing something.
Used to negate imperative verbs, like English "do not" / "don't" in "Please do not (touch) the cat."

etymology: From Debazi sung (prefixually sū) + rȝura.

notes: Alternate causative form of "toikar". Also used to mean "to push over" or similar.
Used to express doubt or a lack of confidence in the preceding statement. Phonemically /kiɾ/.

etymology: Corruption of Early Rokadong ker (12).

notes: Used to show or ask for agreement or reflection. May also be an informal attention-grabbing interjection. While technically this particle is /ɾe/, it's often pronounced identically to "ré" hence the pronunciation guide above.
Used to ask for agreement or reflection. May also be a sarcastic interjection.
Expresses excitement or emphasis.
As in the end of a road, or one end of an object. See "yuya" for the end of an event.

etymology: Calqued from English "enshittification".

notes: Used after dynasty names to refer to their ruling period and the years within, e.g. 100 Kanatasai.
As expected from the derivation, originally meant "villain"; was expanded through semantic drift.

etymology: Backformation from "nemitos" (explode).
Literally "out-piece".

notes: Also refers to erasing something.
Unlike fayarká, which has connotations of tripping, toikar has connotations of being pushed or dropped. However, it is used in the general case as well.
Compound word of "bélcikar" (to be found) and "koshah" (family). Formal; in casual conversation "zahalshah" is preferred.
A portmanteau of "zahal" (friend) and "koshah" (family). Colloquial; in formal writing contexts "bélcikakoshah" is preferred.
Only applies to animals.
Only applies to people.

etymology: From Old Rokadong *mina (five, handful).

notes: Also refers to the red fur of kanvas that have it.

etymology: Backformation from Sainen "tirákaz" (to taste).

notes: As it ends in "naka" (a measure word meaning "thing"), it is its own measure word.

etymology: Contraction of "pá to", a previous form of the dative particle "gun".
notes: Use is verb-dependent. "tah" is similar to the dative particle "gun", in that both are translated as "to" or "for", but the noun "tah" applies to is considered the direct object rather than the indirect object. Due to its etymology, "tah" is also considered the ergative particle.

etymology:
From Proto-Nenta teaguxa "wealth", through Old Nenevesian tiakara "wealth, riches" (modern cátra). Doublet of téguha.

In Nenevesian, cátra also came to mean "fortune, luck" as a result of its use in several phrases and sayings, such as in the phrase cátra lát "lucky hand." Both the canonical and idiomatic definitions were loaned into Rokadong.

From Proto-Nenta teaguxa "wealth", through Old Nenevesian tiakara "wealth, riches" (modern cátra). Doublet of téguha.

In Nenevesian, cátra also came to mean "fortune, luck" as a result of its use in several phrases and sayings, such as in the phrase cátra lát "lucky hand." Both the canonical and idiomatic definitions were loaned into Rokadong.
Irregular application of "dah- -on" circumfix to "karak" (stem for "karakr").
From Old Rokadong nunúka "piece of glass, glassware."

notes: Would probably be a "sela" noun rather than a "kaca" noun in Mangellian Rokadong.
Term for fleshy sweet food. See also "kúzi".

Refers to the edible part of trees specifically; see "cadán" for "fruit" as in "sweet fleshy food", "cadán angga" for "berry",
and "veshan" for "nut" (the name some tree fruits get given).

etymology: From Sadenyan fâwø "to have sex", ultimately from Proto-Nencali pheiva "penis."
notes: Vulgar, hence translation as "to fuck" instead of "to have sex." However, is not used as an amplifier, unlike English "to fuck."

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa "fanna" (type, gender); compare High Karanesa "fand". Doublet of "van".
Clipping of Old Rokadong "leþela tenashanrə sayə", a formal farewell literally translating as "May the stars guide you well".
notes: This farewell is considered slightly informal, in that while you can use it in formal settings, there are more formal ways of saying the same. "Lezeshan" is also less common in continental Rokadong in general.

etymology: Refers to the food group, including products made with wheat or other grains.
Metathesis of ari gyuqa "fire-cooking".
From Sanényan haya (ground).

sample:
"Raisen tak bélnaníkadar gun ila favelo."
Guns are not allowed in this area.

etymology: Often translated as "port", but not to be confused with múspola, which refers to the city a harbor finds itself in.
From nyuharapan "got"; originally used for entering a state.
notes: Used before stative verbs (e.g. hanyar) to indicate that one has entered the state, and before any other verbs to make it perfect ("have <verb>ed" in English).
Originally used as 3uvn, much as singular "they" in English may be used. Considered ungrammatical, as 3s.NB or 4 is preferred, especially in formal environments.
Feminine 3rd person singular pronoun.
Inanimate and agender 3rd person singular pronoun.
Masculine 3rd person singular pronoun.
Nonbinary 3rd person singular pronoun.
Implies divinity specifically; the "safe place" definition of heaven is under "haven".

etymology: From Kairitelan "sãrazhu" ("good day").

notes: From Debazi "sayga".
Literally "to hide/cover oneself".
From Debazi "hailan".
Note that this word is used both for the time on a clock and the duration of time; the word "sátago" is used to explicitly refer to the duration of time.
Refers exclusively to the period of time. For example, the question "What time is it?" would not use sátago, because the question is asking for a point in time, not an interval of time.
Name of the species known in English as figures. Figures are the most similar to real-world humans, so this word would be used for them.

Imposes respect. Effectively the royal "we." It looks entitled for someone not of high status and in a high-formality environment to use, effectively making this the "Karenish I", in terms of 2020s English slang.
Literally "servant". A polite and deferential pronoun. Often used by salespersons.

etymology: From Sanényan chán /t͡ʃa˩˥n/.
notes: Chán is a very informal form of "I" seen primarily in Puram Rokadong, though Pahang Rokadong also has it. It inflects in the same ways as aya, including the -nya clitic.
Literally "friend." Considered a variant of "aya".
Aya is the informal first person singular pronoun, compared to nata. When possessing a noun, it may become a clitic on the noun, of the form -nya.
Nata is the standard first person singular pronoun, more formal than aya. It inflects completely regularly sans the cliticization of the case particles common to all pronouns.
Nyu is only used for intimate partners.
Used when addressing noblepersons.
Most formal 1s pronoun.
Also refers to the cyan fur of kanvas that have it.
Since the removed q from "magata" is irregular, in some dialects, it is still pronounced with a geminated t, [məˈgatːəˌsonə].

etymology: Literally "in-piece".
From the Classical Nenta name "Remuilaga", given to a character who survives in Yukacan mythology as "Remula".
From Classical Nenta nedsaka~nejaka "direction", through Imperial Karanesa nezhak "answer". See also High Karanesa nezik. Doublet of neja.
notes: Also written with the historic initial glottal stop letter.
Used sentence-finally to turn the preceding sentence into a polar question.

sample:
Níkadaten bauha nata zazányar ká.
allow.IMP CNJ[that] 1sg.NTL introduce REFL
Allow me to introduce myself.

notes: While iron can technically be any shape, the common shapes that people would use it in prior to the industrial age (plates and chains) would either be tamis nouns or be prominently used for tamis nouns (armor, shields, fences), hence iron itself being a tamis noun.

While it would be technically correct to use "sinyas" as a prenominal affix for kings, in Quill Kingdom culture, it is common to use a different word, the "dynasty word," in addition to "sinyas." For example, King Remy III's native name is "Kanatasinyas Remi Reneska" ("kanata", meaning beauty, being the dynasty word for Kings Calem II, Remy III, and Iris I).

etymology: Onomatopoeic from Old Rokadong kókó.
notes: Frequently repeated multiple times.
Idiomatically, may also be used where in English one might use "worst."

etymology: Irregular compound of "yukata" (god) and "maya" (word).
Loaned from Liðakuin asjogr "order, command, rule".

notes: Dissimilation occurs in this word, to prevent illegal /ls/.
"rai" means "life, in general", while this means "one's life."
Most directly means "similar to," but also is used in simile where "as (in)" or "as ___ as" may be used.
From Sainen "riyu" (boundary) + "kari" (wall).
Indicates that the verb should be REMPST.

etymology: From Classical Nenta "kannunyə".
From Old Rokadong "kəlaná" (machine, device, engine).
notes: Also used sometimes for "strategy, trick".
For people; if it uses razil it'll use daren.
For animals; if it uses koro it'll use baya.
Dera may be used for any noun whose measure word would be razil (is in the RZ class).
As all nouns are grammatically mass nouns, unya is used regardless.
As all nouns are grammatically mass nouns, unya is used regardless.
A catch-all measure word used for large things, landforms, abstract nouns, thoughts, vehicles, houses, and so on.
Used for kanvas, spirits, and anything else that could be considered people. If the noun "razil" applies to the object, its measure word is "razil."
Used for animals.
Used for small and/or round objects, such as fruits, cups, nuts, and so on.

etymology: Literally "soul chaos."

notes: Like "tamis" (iron), "towan" uses the tamis measure word, in fact, all metals use tamis because towan uses tamis.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa ginganak; use of /dʒ/ appears to be by analogy to native jinkir, which has the same root.

notes: Mass noun of káyang, formed through full reduplication.

etymology: Reduplication of ''líta'' (moon).

notes: The <h> is frequently elided when this circumfix is applied.
Used in almost all contexts in this dialect, instead of ''kaja'' or ''katosha".

etymology: Irregular reduplication of "tákr" (regular would be tatákr), possibly due to "tenatákr" (cause to move).

notes: More casual form of ''kaja''.
Rarely used as a 1st person singular pronoun, especially when talking to oneself.
Name of Quillan in Rokadong.

etymology: Together, the phrase can be taken as "Galaxy Lord of Earth, Sun, and Moon." As seen in the derivations section, each word is "the Milky Way", "Great Earth", "Great Sun", and "Great Moon".
notes: The full name is rarely used compared to shortenings of "Selshan Téshika" or even just "Selshan". They are the creator deity in Yukacan mythology, and the patron deity of the Quill Kingdom. Selshan is said to have created the earth and all the stars in the sky, especially the Sun and Moon. They are described as an androgynous, white or blue-white kanva that guides the world in the Yukacan way.

english definition: name of a group of peoples
etymology: From Proto-Nenta Kana (as in the mythical homeland) + ban "person".
notes: "Kanava" in Rokadong typically refers exclusively to kanvas of Quillan. However, it got borrowed into other languages, where it came to refer to the entire species.
In the Ferkuwian religion, Kana is one of two mythical homelands to the kanva.

etymology: From Debazi pezen "everything, the planet".
notes: Name of the planet of Pezen, equivalent to "Earth" (versus "the earth", known as "Iriseltana" and translated as "Spectradom"). In other words, Pejín/Pezen refers to the celestial object, while Iriseltana/Spectradom refers to the land and seas.
Name of the species known in English as figures.
Word for the fey-like species known in English as "sketch."
Name of the species known as kanvas.

Suaca (translated as "swatches") are cards or tablets in which magic can be embedded, usually using mana-laced paints or similar. This allows someone to activate the swatch to activate a spell - usually, a simple one, like throwing a fireball or freezing the surface of a body of water. However, multiple swatches can be combined together to make more powerful magic.
Known as "quills" in English, these are fairy-like small humanoid creatures said to be born from a magic papyrus.
The official name of the Rokadong script.
An unofficial name of the Rokadong script.

etymology: Irregular deverbalization form of Old Rokadong rathorə "to make."

notes: For sequences.
For locations.
Used to negate verbs and adjectives, like English "did not" in "I did not have sex with that woman."
Used to negate verbs and adjectives, like English "did not" in "I did not have sex with that woman."
Used to negate nouns, like English "not a" in "I am not a crook" or "no" in "No President should be a criminal."

etymology: From Debazi "pall(a/i/u)" (negation particle).
notes: Equivalent to the English prefix "a-".
In the sense of "out of."
Marks that a noun is in the genitive.
4th person pronoun.
Reflexive pronoun generally.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa kátha, from Old High Kanafan katth.
From Sanenyan "harrosa" (guardian).
From Old High Kanafan myd (to split, part, slice), through Imperial Karanesa mûra. Compare High Karanesa mîd.

notes: In some Oceanic dialects, it is pronounced meneh /meneʔ/.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa.

notes: Basically "place of (noun this circumfix is applied to)". The r is dropped if the next morpheme starts with a liquid.
Basically "place of (noun this circumfix is applied to)". The r is dropped if the next morpheme starts with a liquid.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa tôsaká "wandering star". Doublet of sósah.
notes: The sense meaning "the Earth" is more recent.

etymology: Doublet of toska.

notes: Yes, it's a gustar-like verb for to like... remember, *all* emotion verbs are experiential verbs in Rokadong.
Placed after any semi-formal or formal 2nd person singular pronoun to pluralize it.
Placed after any informal 2nd person singular pronoun to pluralize it.

etymology: Literally "bay city", as bays are naturally good at being port towns. Not to be confused with kerés, which refers to the harbor itself.

notes: Also refers to internet posts.

etymology: Clipping of "asur laki kadi" (to save/hold for tomorrow).
notes: Sometimes also spelled with the ka letter instead of a final glottal stop.

etymology: From Debazi fithra "goal, purpose."
From Proto-Nenta *qilla (quality).
notes: The k is dropped if the previous morpheme starts with a plosive other than /ʔ/.

etymology: Ultimately, from Proto-Nensein *itta (quality particle).
notes: The t is dropped if the next morpheme starts with a consonant (other than /j/). -kil is preferred, as it- is more likely to be considered part of a word's root.
Reduction of "sena-tena", a rhyming duplication of "tenar".

etymology: From Liðakuin "ðusihr sehné" (reflection).
From Sainen "akatu" (same meaning, originally "akantou").

notes: Refers to rice to be served loose, such as a side of rice in Tex-Mex food or the base for Chinglish food, rather than being turned into a rice cake or similar.

etymology: Reduplication of "nikada" (allowance).

notes: Means "rolled-up object" generally, as in both "roll of bread" and "roll of yarn".

etymology: Partial reduplication of rukr, which augments the verb.

notes: From "anmawíkr" "to be sad".

etymology: Irregular verbalization; effectively tena-sema-r "to cause peace". The s was originally /θ/ and due to stress being on the ma, it reduced to /t/ instead of /s/.
From Debazi micela "lie, false".
From Old Rokadong nunúka "piece of glass, glassware."
Exactly what it sounds like.
notes: Irregular spelling as a result of recent loaning; meant to imply [itʷita] by analogy to the orthography that [CʲV] uses.

etymology: From nyupan (formal form of nyuwa) + bispa (to get sick).
From Imperial Karanesa shókuda.
Literally "coin-ish", backformed from the expansion of "firos" (coin).
From Imperial Karanesa mitgina, a compound of mitos "piece, fragment" + gina "rock".

notes: In some Oceanic dialects, it is pronounced meneh /meneʔ/.
As in speed only; compare Spanish "lento" (as opposed to Spanish "tardo" which does refer to both physical and mental slowness).

etymology: Mashed together "gingka" (rock), "téril" (wood), "towan" (metal).

notes: Slightly younger word in Rokadong than "kita". See also "naita".
As in hot or picante.
In many compound words, "sela" either has a connotation of, or better translates to, "one's soul" - the Debazi-loaned "raura" is the preferred scientific term for the points of light as a result.

etymology: From Debazi rȝura, with the same meaning.
notes: Uncommonly seen alone in most dialects. Instead, it is more common to see "raura" in a compound word, such as "anfukaraura" (stellar remnant).
May also be a jang noun if written down (as in a book).
Also used to refer to a direction, e.g. "straight ahead" (see also "direct").

etymology: From Classical Nenta "megeqta" (confusion).
notes: Since the removed q is irregular, in some dialects, it is still pronounced with a geminated t, [məˈgatːə].

etymology: From Classical Nenta matəqu "slab, especially of rock."

notes: Also the adjective.

etymology: From Sainen "tirákaz" (to taste).

notes: Portmanteau of tenakayúr "to cause to learn."

etymology: From Sainen "meisa" (time) + Rokadong "-kil" (affix for quality or abstraction).

notes: May also be a pronoun.
Emphasizes "ibi" (that).
3rd person informal plural pronoun originally referring to female groups. Considered ungrammatical and only used in conservative dialects.
3rd person formal plural pronoun.

etymology: Literally "razil" (person) + "ibi" (that).
notes: 3rd person formal plural pronoun.
3rd person formal plural pronoun.
3rd person informal plural pronoun originally referring to nonbinary groups, now preferred regardless of the gender of the constituents.
3rd person informal plural pronoun originally referring to male groups. Considered ungrammatical and only used in conservative dialects.

etymology: From Middle Rokadong "káca" (boulder). Borrowed from Old Sanenyan "kassha" (Modern Sanenyan kàsha).
Ultimately, from Proto-Nenta noqə~noq "physical object".
notes: Is its own measure word. Generally, "noka" is used for physical objects only.
Reduplication of "soka", emphasizing the word.
Refer to "míha" for the temporal sense of the English word "time".
Refers to the temporal sense of "time", not the occurence sense (e.g. "first time").

etymology: From Proto-Nenta teaguxoh "wealth, riches", which expanded into meaning "net worth" and then "total", before the first two meanings were superseded by what in Modern Rokadong is the word magaha. No relation to the word "tékuha".

notes:
Used in reference to species with multiple forms, or species that metamorphose such as caterpillars.
"Ca" (as) follows this word rather than the expected "pe" (to) of English, as the verb also means disguise.

etymology: From Early Rokadong ker (12) and Modern Rokadong de (2).
From an Old Rokadong verb tengar "to combine", itself a Sanenyan loan from qanha "to bundle, to combine".

Folk etymology: From "tenar" + "aki".
Actual etymology: From an Old Rokadong verb tengar "to combine", itself a Sanenyan loan from qanha "to bundle, to combine".
Formed from Matelian asateli "diamond", ultimately from Sãdenyán hashrĩl "diamond, gemstone, valuable".
notes: The expected form would be *astelil, but the -an suffix is used instead, likely to avoid /lil/.
As the word ends in "noka", this word doesn't take a measure word.

etymology: From Classical Nenta hasirí "conflict, skirmish."
Reduplication of "lápr" (to see).
From Classical Nenta asa korong "fresh water."

notes: May also be used as 1sg.CAS.
Exclusive "we" - the speaker is not included.

etymology: Clipping of ''penggaraza'' (seven suns).
Portmanteau of "ila kel".
Portmanteau of "kesa míha" ("where (in) time").
notes: When used in a question, this word is typically accompanied by the locative marker "gun".

etymology: Formed by analogy to "ike" and "ibisa".
notes: When used in a question, this word is typically accompanied by the locative marker "gun".

etymology: Formed by analogy to "ike" and either the pronoun "zena" or the pronoun "lan".

notes: Formally, it needs to be joined by "senten".
When "wishing for", this verb is followed by the conjunction "tah", rather than the expected dative particle "gun".

etymology: From Classical Nenta "remuy, ramuy" (dream).

notes: Adpositional phrase, much like Spanish "conmigo".
This word may also itself be a measure word-esque noun. [numeral]jang-jang means "word with length [numeral]." In Rokadong script, jang is 2 letters (ja + final ng), so jang-jang is a kojang-jang.
Refers to any labor, though it connotes that the person's job is "unskilled" labor.

etymology: From Imperial Karanesa tôsaká "wandering star". Doublet of sósah.
notes: The sense meaning "the Earth" is more recent.

etymology: Backformation from súnzatenasiong.
notes: Literally "to cause to be shit." Vulgar.
Used to express shock. Phonemically /kiɾ/.
May also itself be used as a counter word to describe someone's age, such as in "dekanaki kótan" (21 years old).
A more assertive form of "vai", used when one is sure about something. Phonemically /ɾu/.
Formal masculine "you". Equivalent to English "sir".
Use zena outside of oceanic dialects. Considered a variant of zena.
Zena is the informal second person singular pronoun, when compared to talah. It may form a clitic suffix on the noun it is possessing, of -za.
Agender and inanimate variant of zena.
Semi-formal "you".
Male variant of zena.
Semi-formal "you".
Formal feminine "you". Equivalent to English "madam".
Formal "you" used when addressing a government official. Equivalent to English "your Honour".
Semi-formal plural "you." "Talah" is preferred.
Semi-formal plural "you."
Informal plural "you." Often equivalent to y'all.
Nonbinary variant of zena.
Humble "you" used when addressing a nobleperson. Equivalent to English "my lord."
Formal nonbinary "you". Rarer than ludi or lunu. Older speakers in particular are likely to use ludi instead of luvi. Has no direct English translation, other than perhaps "sir".

etymology: From Sanényan zù /t͡su˥˩/
notes: Zú is a very informal form of "you" found primarily in Puram Rokadong.
Female variant of zena.
Irregular semi-formal plural "you," considered a softening of "tau tékuha". Often used by a boss or coach when addressing their team.
Semi-formal plural "you." "Tau" is preferred.
Semi-formal plural "you."
